entry.title: Q4 2025 Innovations: SAP Enterprise Service Management
entry.content:
Welcome to the quarterly innovation highlights for  SAP Enterprise Service Management for Q4 2025.  Here, I want to feature some key capabilities that have been released within the past three months. We invite you to register for our Q4 2025 Innovations webcast for SAP Enterprise Management and Service Cloud on Tuesday, January 27th and SAP Sales Cloud and Foundation on Wednesday, January 28th ensuring you stay up-to-date on all the innovations and improvements delivered in Q4 2025.

Also, Learn more about the latest Q4 2025 innovations across the SAP CX portfolio here.

What‚Äôs New in SAP Enterprise Service Management
 SAP Enterprise Management is unifying internal service delivery operations across the globe. AI is driving measurable results in workplace productivity and stay tuned for an update on the progress of our ESM@SAP initiative ‚Äì with already more than 1200 support agents across more than 10 use cases from learning to finance and people and culture using SAP ESM!  Tight integration with the SAP Cloud ERP applications is driving quick deployments, quick time-to-value and bringing users high satisfaction by delivering a truly unified workspace.

Before we jump into the highlights,  please remember to review Kirsi‚Äôs Q4 2025 release blog for SAP Service Cloud blog which provides additional innovation highlights benefiting SAP Enterprise Service Management as well!

Now, let me introduce you to some Q4 2025 innovations spanning across useability, extensibility, automation and more!

Personalized KPI Cards in Home Page & Cases:

Personalized KPI cards enables business level configuration of real time app data presented in the home page or in cases to ensure support agents and managers have a pulse on performance. Bringing together information from various applications helps to ensure KPI‚Äôs are meaningful and deliver the right insights.

Object-Based Navigation in Mashups

Mashups enable a unified workspace and align various parameters into the business context. However, it is common, especially with custom applications for support agents to work in a separate browser tab.  This navigation enables a quick view to open from custom timeline events in a new browser tab while maintain key parameters.

Navigate to Custom UI‚Äôs from Mashups

Ease of navigation is key for support agents. Ensuring processes can be modeled effectively is critical to not only ensure agent satisfaction but to facilitate quick resolutions. Navigation from mashups is now expanded to custom UI‚Äôs.

Shortcuts in the Shell Bar

Recent items and favorites have been added to the shortcuts in the shell bar.  Service agents can now access a quick list of their favorites with a click in the shell bar reducing navigation steps. Additionally, an agent can easily retrieve complex tasks or activities they have in-work with one click to view the last 15 recent items. They can bypass menus and searches for one-click access to active work items.

Reference field usage in the Case

The ability to use fields from other entities such as employee, supplier or customer in the case is supports context and processing. Enabling these entities as reference fields in the case processes such as autoflow or rules and in defining customer logic helps streamline processes for the support agent and enables deep context ensuring the right data is considered and included in case resolution steps.

Intent-Based Navigation

Embedded analytics drive key insights to user, now with intent-based navigation a user can go from our embedded SAP Analytics Cloud directly to a case or other entity and make updates without having to click through menu navigation. This truly is ‚Äúfrom insights to action,‚Äù in just a click or two. Check out more details and a video on Intent-Based Navigation in my colleague Shameek‚Äôs blog.  

Case Step Pre-Conditions including Business Documents

Business document integration with SAP Enterprise Service Management creates clean and streamlined experiences for support issues on invoices, disputes and other documents. With the ability to define case step pre-conditions based on values in these business documents case processes and flows can be automated to reflect business document updates.  As an example, if an invoice status changes to 'posted' then a related case can be set to 'closed' automatically without further support.

WalkMe In-App Help

WalkMe is an AI-powered digital adoption platform integrated across SAP Cloud ERP applications and is now integrated with SAP Enterprise Service Management. WalkMe not only accelerates onboarding and new agent training, it enables intuitive, in-app guidance for support agents on-demand. With WalkMe, teams can create step-by-step walkthroughs and contextual tips directly within the application. Additionally, WalkMe provides visibility into where agents encounter friction‚Äîhelping organizations continuously optimize their service processes.

Form Attachments

An enhancement to the existing dynamic forms capability enables form-based inquiry to include processes-specific documents. Employees or other users can upload relevant documents during request submission reducing follow-ups or additional cycles to gather missing information. As per the case type, the intake form can be defined to designate specific attachments as required reducing errors and reducing risk, especially valuable with  case flows for audits and compliance regulations.

Additional

Use the SAP Enterprise Service Management managed tag when posting on SAP ESM topics! And thank you for your active participation in the community. We all benefit from hearing about successes and challenges with SAP Enterprise Service Management and how you‚Äôre using the solution. 

If you feel you have missed some innovations ‚Äì check the What‚Äôs New ‚Äì and filter by a date range to see all the innovations and improvements  delivered. Never miss an innovation!

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud Test Automation Tool in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud Edition CE2602
entry.content:
Introduction 

As we continue to innovate and enhance the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Test Automation Tool (TAT), the CE2602 release brings powerful new capabilities designed to make post-upgrade testing smarter, faster, and more efficient. In this blog, I‚Äôll walk you through the latest features delivered with CE2602, including advanced comparison options in the Post Upgrade Test (PUT) App, enhanced TDC AutoBind integration, and a new capability in i-TS for Smart Execution. These improvements aim to simplify test management, expand coverage, and reduce manual effort‚Äîhelping you achieve greater accuracy and productivity in your testing workflows.

Full Scope Comparison (PUT application)

The Full Scope Comparison feature provides a holistic view of two PUT executions (Standard & Custom) across different releases or runs.

  • Comprehensive Analysis: Compare two complete PUT executions for detailed insights.
  • Side-by-Side Summary: View execution details, triggers, and timestamps for quick reference.
  • Impact Identification: Rapidly detect post-upgrade changes across the entire PUT landscape for thorough validation and risk mitigation.

Fig.1 : Execution comparator showcasing the comparison feature of two test runs

Comparison of Custom Automates (PUT application)

This feature enables detailed analysis of custom automated test plans across different PUT runs.

  • Cross-Run Comparison: Analyse custom PUT automated test plans executed in two different runs.
  • Instance-Level Status: Displays detailed status for each test plan, such as:
    • Success
    • Failed
    • Pre-checks Failed
    • Cancelled

Fig.2 : Showcases comparison support for customer test plans

Enhanced AutoBind for Test Data Container Integration

AutoBind logic has been significantly improved to make test setup faster and more accurate.

  • Intelligent Mapping: Maps Test Data Container (TDC) fields to script labels for both Standard & PUT automates.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures precise alignment between test data and scripts.
  • Reduced Manual Effort: Minimises manual intervention during test setup.

Fig. 3 : Showcases enhanced auto bind capability for TDC integration

Scoping Capability (PUT application)

The new Smart Execution feature enhances flexibility by allowing users to include i-TS recommended scope along with custom scope in custom variants.

  • Comprehensive Coverage: Combine i-TS recommended processes with standard and custom-defined processes while executing a custom variant for PUT.
  • Flexible Execution: Provides control to selectively merge scopes for a unified test run.
  • Improved Accuracy: Ensures critical i-TS recommended scenarios are validated alongside custom flows for reliable post-upgrade assessment.

Fig. 4 : Showcases capability to include i-TS recommended processes while executing a custom variant for PUT

Why It Matters

These updates significantly improve testing efficiency, enhance data accuracy, reduce manual setup effort, and boost overall productivity across all post-upgrade test automation workflows.

SAP Delivered Standard Automates

The total list of SAP delivered automated test scripts are 505 for 2602 release and can be accessed via link ‚Äì Automated Test Scripts Index‚Äù. This includes 26 new scope items which were added this release.

Further detailed change information about the standard automate is available in the ‚ÄúTest Script Release Change Information‚Äù.

Learn More: 

Important Links and Updates

We have created a new Learning Hub course for an overview of the tool. This is a good starting point for anyone who is new to the tool or want to get an overview of the new features we have added over the past couple of years. [Before you can access the link, a one-time registration in the SAP Learning Hub, edition for SAP Enterprise Support, is required. A detailed step-by-step guidance can be found here]

 As part of our PUT 2.0 Enablement also we have created a set of short videos which cover the most important aspects of the process. The video playlist can be accessed here.

 Links to other important blogs:

  • How to get started with the Test Automation Tool for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 

Please bookmark the test automation community page to keep up with the latest updates happening in the test automation space.

For more details on the functionality please refer the links below:

  • Post-Upgrade Tests App
  • Intelligent Test Scoper (i-TS) 
  • Manage Upgrade Tests 
  • Manage Your Test Processes
  • Test Your Processes
  • Test Data Container
  • Analyze Automated Test Results
  • Configure Conditional Authentication
  • Also refer FAQs

Questions, feedback, or tips? Comment below or connect with us on SAP Community! Follow the PSCC_Enablement tag to stay up to date with our latest blog posts.

Follow us on @SAP and #S4HANA, and myself on LinkedIn.

üîéFind All of Our Assets

SAP S/4HANA Cloud is the foundation of the intelligent, sustainable enterprise and is an innovative, robust, and scalable ERP. We at Cloud ERP Product Success and Cloud Co-Innovation offer a service as versatile as our product itself. Check out the numerous offerings our team has created for you below:

entry.title: Don't Let Your Integration Take a Coffee Break: Client Certificate Changes In 2026!
entry.content:
Introduction

If integrations were people, you‚Äôd dread them slipping out for coffee breaks just when you need them most. SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, Integrated Business Planning (IBP), and SAP Marketing Cloud (SMC) are all about to experience an important update to how client certificates are issued. This change, prompted by evolving industry standards, involves a change of the Certificate Authority (CA) for the Default Client certificate. It‚Äôs important to note that this CA change has the potential to cause one of those dreaded coffee breaks‚Äîdisruptions in connectivity‚Äîif not handled properly.

Here‚Äôs what‚Äôs happening, who should pay attention, and how to keep your setup on track.

Who Is Affected?

If you use the Client Default certificate for outbound authentication in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, or SMC, this change applies to you. Anyone relying on these certificates for outbound integrations should pay attention, as missing the update could lead to disruptions in communication.

This only applies to customer managed integration scenarios. SAP managed ones will be taken care of by SAP, of course.

What Is Changing?

Currently, the Default Client certificates for outbound communication are issued by DigiCert. In February 2026, SAP Cloud Root CA becomes the new certificate authority for newly issued client certificates. You‚Äôll also notice updates to certificate subject names, including additional organizational fields. These changes will be present in all new client certificates issued during routine rotation.

To help visualize the upcoming changes, here‚Äôs a quick comparison of the old and new default client certificates:

Certificate Attribute

Old (Before Rotation)

New (After Rotation)

Subject

CN=<your tenant hostname>

CN=<your tenant hostname>
OU=<some UID>

Issuer

DigiCert Global G2

SAP Cloud Root CA

Extended Key Usage

Client Authentication,
Server Authentication

Client Authentication

The new OU value is specific to the product (S/4/IBP/ SMC) and will remain the same during future certificate rotations.

Timeline and Notification: When and How Will You be Informed?

New systems will receive client certificates signed by SAP Cloud Root CA starting late March 2026. Existing systems will begin renewal with a staging certificate from late February 2026, fully transitioning during their next scheduled key rotation. In case you wonder: the fact that these dates are close to the 2602 release is a pure coincidence. System upgrades and certificate changes are separate processes.
The rotation schedule and rotation process do not change. There will be no additional certificate rotation.

Example: if your current Client Default certificate is valid until April 2026, the CA change will happen in April for you. If your certificate expires in November, you‚Äôll keep your DigiCert certificate until November and then switch to SAP Cloud Root CA.

The usual notification email about certificate rotation will include additional details about the change in Certificate Authority. Please review it carefully to ensure you understand the updates and can take the right actions in response. The process for certificate rotation is described on this help page.

Potential Issues and Required Action

For clarity, we'll refer to the system, tenant, service, or device that receives and validates connections from your SAP cloud tenant (S/4 cloud, IBP, SMC) as the target environment. Such target environments could be anything from BTP apps, SAP solutions like SAP Ariba or SAP SuccessFactors, third-party products running in the cloud or on-premises, or even custom-built applications.

How Things Might Break

Misalignment of configurations in your SAP cloud tenant and the target environment can lead to two categories of issues:

  • CA Trust Failures: If your target environment does not trust the SAP Cloud Root CA, it will reject the new certificate. In these cases, the mutual TLS (mTLS) handshake fails, and communication is blocked at the TLS layer. No HTTP error code is returned.
  • User / System / Identity Mapping Errors: in the target environment, the certificate metadata (subject, issuer) is mapped to the identity of a user or process. Consequently, if the mapping is not changed to use the new subject and issuer, authorization errors (such as HTTP 403 or 401) will happen. Depending on the implementation of the target environment, TLS errors could also occur.

Technical Aside: Certificate Pinning vs CA Trust

For certificate-based authentication, most target environments will rely on CA trust, where the target environment validates the certificate‚Äôs chain up to a trusted root CA. With the switch to SAP Cloud Root CA, you must add this CA to the trust store in the target environment and check your user mapping logic.

For environments using certificate pinning, simply upload the new certificate when the rotation occurs. In this case, the certificate is identified by the fingerprint of the certificate‚Äôs key rather than the metadata of the certificate (i.e. subject and issuer). Target environments using certificate pinning must be updated every time the certificate rotates ‚Äì the CA change does not make a difference here.

Required Actions for Customers

To maintain uninterrupted integrations, customers using the Client Default certificate for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, IBP, and SMC should:

  1. Update CA Trust: Make sure the SAP Cloud Root CA is trusted by your target environment. You can download the root certificate from the SAP Trust Center.
  2. Adjust User/System/Identity Mapping: Update your mapping logic to recognize the new certificate subject and issuer, ensuring the target environment properly identifies and authorizes the incoming connection.

More information on the topic is available in SAP note 3677763 as well as the relevant help pages:

  • How to Handle Default Client Certificate Renewal
  • Set Up Certificate-to-User Mapping (SAP Cloud Integration and SAP Marketing Cloud)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for Integration Flow Processing (SAP Integration Suite)
  • Client Certificate Authentication for API Clients (SAP Integration Suite)

Conclusion

While this certificate update might seem like an invitation for your integrations to sneak away for a coffee break, staying alert and updating your trust stores and mappings in your target environment will keep everything running without interruption. Pay attention to notification emails‚Äîso your integrations never miss a beat (or a sip).

entry.title: S/4HANA Q2C Sales Flexibility - Default Validity Date on Sales Contracts via CPF
entry.content:
Background:

The validity of sales contract identify the certain period that sales representative can main the specific goods are to be sold and under which conditions or special discounts, the sales contracts are valid for this certain time period and the customer fulfill a sales contract by issuing release orders.

Previously, the valid to date of sales contract is not initiated as default, and for quantity contract, the valid from date is not proposed neither, therefore the sales representative has to maintain them correspondingly, otherwise the sales contract is not complete to issue the release orders.

Starting from the S/4HANA Public Cloud release 2602, the default valid from date of sales contract is provided that system uses the creation date as valid-from date.

Additionally, a new flexible solution is provided for configuration expert to define rules that the system uses to determine valid-to dates for sales contracts. These rules enable the flexible calculation of valid-to date based on the calendar and offset rules. This blog illustrates how to maintain configurations to enable flexible determination of valid-to date.

For more details, please see SAP help documentation (link).

CPF

CPF(Configurable Parameter and Formula) is a framework to create flexible formulas to calculate the valid-to date default. CPF allows to specify defaulting rules based on a broad set of parameters in addition to the contract type.

For example, one customer has two sales organizations: 1010 and 1710. Different leading days to calculate the valid to date can be defined for the different sales organizations whilst using the same contract type (CQ)

Sales Document TypeSales OrganizationOffset days
CQ101080
CQ171090

Configuration Steps

Different from On-Premise and Private Cloud system user using Transaction code SPRO to change configurations in backend, user with role ‚ÄúSAP_BR_BPC_EXPERT‚Äù needs to use the following SSCUIs to maintain configuration settings in S/4HANA Cloud.

  • Define the Parameter Catalog
  • Define Rules to determine Factory Calendar
  • Define Formulas and maintain the Decision Table
  • Define Custom Routines for Validity Date
  • Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types

1. Define the Parameter Catalog

SSCUI 105546, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates)

The parameters which can be used as conditions of the decision table can be maintained. There are some standard parameters are provided. Custom fields on sales doc header can be added as custom specific parameters.

2. Define Rules to Determine Factory Calendar

SSCUI 103829, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates->Define Rules to Determine Factory Calendar)

The valid-to date can be proposed by the working days which is defined in factory calendar. For example, the factory calendar is determined by:

  • Firstly, check whether there is a calendar maintained in the sales organization
  • If not, then check whether there is a calendar
  • If still not, then the calendar in the rule is used

3. Define Formulas and Maintain the Decision Table

SSCUI 105547, path: Configure Your Solution->Sales->Sales Order Management and Processing->Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates->Define Formulas for Validity Dates.

A formula consists out of a set of freely configurable parameters which are needed for the execution of the formula and a set of (usage-dependent) tasks, defining what is supposed to be done. The formula-specific implementation of a task, the CPF Routine, is then the logic to be executed. Below steps are required to define a formula:

  1. Define a formula ID 
  2. Assign formula parameters
  3. Define the priority of the parameters
  4. Maintain the decision table

3.1 Define a formula ID

The formula ID is used to assigned to one adaptation scenario for sales contact usage, and the default usage task is SET_VALID_TO_DATE.

3.2 Assign Formula Parameters

Parameter ‚ÄòVALID_TO_DATE‚Äô is pre-maintained as returning result. Other parameter catalog maintained in SSCUI 105546 ‚ÄòDefine Parameter Catalog for Validity Dates‚Äô can be assigned to the formula.

3.3 Define the Priority of the Formula Parameters

In step ‚ÄòAssign Parameter Priority‚Äô, the priority can be set to the formula parameters which have been assigned to the formula.

3.4 Maintain the Decision Table

The decision table is generated automatically after the priority of the parameter have been defined. The assigned formula parameters can be maintained as conditions. Below fields can be maintained to specify how to calculate the valid-to date:

  • Absolute Offset (in days) 
  • A rule to determine the factory calendar
  • Additional rule to calculate the valid-to date

Additional Relative Offset

Based on given valid-from date, absolute offset, and calendar rule, the system gets an initial valid-to date. Here you can choose how the system processes the initial date to determine the final date. For example, you can choose the first working day in the initially proposed week as the final valid-to date.

4. Define Custom Routines for Validity Date

SSCUI 105548, path: Configure Your Solution -> Sales -> Sales Order Management and Processing -> Custom Adaptations for Validity Dates -> Custom Routines for Validity Dates of Sales Documents.

A customer routine is entrance to enable the Formula of CPF framework, you can define new routine numbers and then assign enhancement ID to the defined routine. You can choose the default Process Enhancement Option task and select the Implementation Type B ‚Äì Configurable Parameters and Form.

  • Specify the ID and description of the routine
  • Select the process enhancement option task as ‚ÄòSD_SLS_FLEX_VALID_TO_DATE‚Äô
  • Specify which formula you would like to use in this routine

5. Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types

SSCUI 103823, path: Configure Your Solution -> Sales -> Sales Order Management and Processing -> Sales Documents -> Assign Custom Routines to Sales Document Types.

Once the customer routine is defined, it can be assigned to one sales contract type, to enable CPF rules in sales document processing, the custom routine defined in previous step shall be linked to the sales document type.

The customer routine can be assigned to the document type with categories. The section ‚ÄòValidity Date‚Äô is only available for sales document types with category Sales Contract. For others the field will be read-only.

Sales Contract Testing

Here we are referring decision table entries with below data:

Sales Document TypeSales OrganizationDistribution ChannelDivisionAbsolute OffsetFactory Calendar RuleAdditional Relative Offset
CQ1010100080ZKET 
CQ1710100090 B

Assuming: the sales contract valid from date is 11/25/2025.

When creating sales contract with type CQ and sales area 1710/10/00, system will hint the second line of decision table. The valid to date determines to 02/28/2026 which considers the initial valid from date: 11/25/2025, absolute offset: 90 and additional relative offset: B - last day of month.

1. Log into S/4HANA Cloud system using user with role ‚ÄúSAP_BR_INTERNAL_SALES_REP‚Äù.

2. Create a sales contract in Manage Sales Contracts ‚Äì Version 2

When creating sales contract, the valid-to fields will be set automatically. When changing the valid-from date during the creation, the valid-to date will also be recalculated automatically. For example, when entering the create view, the valid-to date is immediately set as 90 days after the valid-from date. If changing the valid-from date, the valid-to date is immediately updated to 90 days after the valid-from date.

Sales Organization 1710:

Additional Notes

  • This functionality is also available for sales quotation and sales inquiry.
  • This functionality is also available when creating sales quotation via OData API. An exception is creating sales quotation via OData API with reference. In this case, the automatic determination of valid-to date will not be triggered.
  • Automatically setting the valid-to data is only available when creating sales contracts. It will not be triggered when editing an existing sales contract.

entry.title: Request Current Market Data - Currency rates(Exchange rates)
entry.content:
SAP Market Data Management supports the following market data classes:

  • Currency rates (exchange rates)
  • Interest rates
  • Basis spreads
  • Credit spreads
  • General volatilities
  • FX swap rates
  • Security prices

This article covers: How to configure and request the Currency Exchange Rates Datafeed.

Datafeed incorporates current and historic market data into your financial transactions by means of the different SAP Market Rates Management services.

  • Define the data sources that can be accessed from the system in the configuration activity 'Define Data Sources for Datafeed'.
  • Subscribe to one of the following Market Rates Management service packages:
    a.) SAP Market Rates Management - Refinitiv data option: This is a paid service that is built for productive usage. It provides market data from Refinitiv, data provider.
    b.) SAP Market Rates Management - Bring Your Own Rates data option: This service can be used to import your own data that you have procured or licensed directly with data providers. Market rates are uploaded and downloaded using the SAP Market Rates Management service upload and download APIs.
  • Set up a communication arrangement for the SAP Treasury Market Rate Integration (SAP_COM_0203).
  • Translation tables must be defined before running any task to request market data and need to be set up only once for each type of market data. Assign Currency Notations ‚Äì Datafeed app lets you define how currency exchange rates are imported from your datafeed provider and allows you to manually maintain translation tables between the datafeed and your master data.
  • To test your datafeed setup, run the apps Request Current Market Data and Request Historical Market Data.
  • Market data requests can be automated using the scheduling options available in the Request Current Market Data job template within the Schedule Treasury Back Office Jobs app.

Example

We take an example of the Bring Your Own Rates data option(BYOR).

  • Upload market rates from any source to the SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option APIs.

The instrument class and data provider are specified, such as instrument class 01 for currencies and data provider Y001 for SAP Business Technology Platform‚Äìbased market data.
  • Enter translation tables manually in the Assign Currency Notations ‚Äì Datafeed app to map datafeed values to your master data.

  • To set up the translation table for the Refinitiv data option, refer Reuters Instrument Codes (RICs)
  • Run Request Current Market Data.
  • Verify the result for market data request
References:
  1. Setup instructions for the 1S4 scope item.
  2. Market Data Management
  3. Request Market Data
  4. Datafeed
  5. SAP Market Rates Management, Refinitiv data option.
  6. SAP Market Rates Management, Bring Your Own Rates data option

entry.title: My First Situation with the Extended Framework
entry.content:
Situation Handling notifies users about issues requiring their attention. With the extended framework for Situation Handling, you can define situations for your business needs.

This blog post illustrates how you can create a situation quickly and with minimal configuration. It outlines the core concept of the extended framework for Situation Handling and guides you in defining your own situation use case.

The configuration relates to the extended framework for Situation Handling which has been available since SAP S/4HANA Cloud 2202 and SAP S/4HANA 2021 FPS2.

 

Introductory Words

The extended framework for Situation Handling is very powerful. In turn, it‚Äôs not always easy to get started. To provide you with a straightforward path, this blog post focuses on the minimal viable configuration to create a situation instance.

The Apps

The configuration of Situation Handling is set up across three apps to maximize reuse. While it may seem complex at first, the advantages become clear as you create multiple use cases. The configuration effort decreases substantially with each new use case. The apps also align with different business roles supporting technical and business-oriented responsibilities.

  • Manage Situation Objects ‚Äì reuse the artifacts from the applications, such as CDS views, events, and navigation targets, for defining a situation object.
  • Manage Situation Scenarios ‚Äì map the affected object (anchor object) with trigger objects and trigger behaviors create, update, and remove.
  • Manage Situation Types ‚Äì add logic to the anchor and trigger objects to define the use case

To inform the right users we additionally use the Manage Teams and Responsibilities app.

The Use Case

The extended framework for Situation Handling also comes with a demo app that serves as exploratory sandbox. We use the Situation Handling Demo app and its artifacts for the minimal configuration.

The demo app represents a fictional flight booking system. Your first situation will inform about flights that are scheduled within the next three days.

 

Minimal Configuration

Let‚Äôs define the minimal set-up to create a situation.

Manage Situation Objects

The situation object represents a business object. It reuses existing application artifacts that are relevant to your business scope. The core of a situation object is the structure, a CDS view. The CDS view needs to be allowlisted and needs a unique key.

Log-in as Extensibility Specialist to your system and open the app Manage Situation Objects.

Create a new object and enter the object ID, the name, description, and select the SAP object type.

General information of situation object

Then you add the CDS view that contains the data you want to monitor. The CDS view is part of the object‚Äôs structure. Create a new structure and enter a description. Select the structure type, the structure name (the reference to the CDS view), and the SAP object node type. For personal data simply select no fields.

CDS structure of situation object

Additionally, you add the semantic key that represents the situation object on the UI. For the flight object we choose the carrier ID, the connection ID and the flight date from the object‚Äôs CDS view. It will show, for example, as LH/403/20251224.

Then choose Apply and Create. Your first situation object is set.

Manage Situation Scenarios

The situation scenario relates to the object that is affected by a situation (anchor object). Additionally, it contains the objects that can trigger a situation.

Background:  The trigger object can be the same as the anchor object - for example, if you want to monitor the data of the anchor object‚Äôs CDS view. The trigger object can also be another situation object. In our flight example, the trigger object could be the booking object, and the anchor object is the flight.

The trigger object also comes with a trigger behavior. The trigger object can be created or updated; it can also be removed.

In our example, we use the Flight object, both as anchor and as trigger object with the behavior add / update.

Open the app Manage Situation Scenarios.

Create a new scenario with ID, name, and description. Provide the scenario type and the object structure type. You also select the responsibility context ID which links Responsibility Management to Situation Handling to be able to identify the right users who need to be informed about the situation.

General information of situation scenario

Then you add the reference to the object that is affected by the situation, the anchor object. Select the object ID. Chose the object structure ID (an object can have multiple structures) and a key field that uniquely identifies your anchor object. The key field is part of the structure‚Äôs CDS view.

Reference to anchor object

Next you define the situation trigger with name and description. As we want to check the CDS fields regularly we create a batch-based trigger.

Batch-based situation trigger

Finally, you need to add the reference to the trigger object like you did for the anchor object. Select the object ID, the object structure ID, and the object key field. Additionally select the relevant object behavior. In our example, it‚Äôs add/update because we want to monitor flight data that is new or changed.

Reference to trigger object

Choose Apply and Create. Your scenario is done.

Log-off as Extensibility Specialist and log-in as Business Process Configuration Expert.

Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended

In the  Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended app you define the logic when a situation is detected and who should be informed about it.

Background: The app supports the idea of reuse as well. You can create a situation template that serves as blueprint. And you can derive multiple situation types from it. The blueprint, for example, defines the monitoring of flights. Flight monitoring may require different conditions for different regions. For this purpose, you can derive multiple situation types from the template that contain all settings from the blueprint. You only need to adjust the conditions for the specific regions.

In our use case we want to identify flights that are scheduled within the next three days. Therefore, we want to check the flight data daily and use the batch-based situation trigger from the scenario. In the condition section we define the relevant period of next 3 days.

Open the app Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended.

Create a new template from the scenario My First Scenario. Enter general data that describes the template: the scenario ID, the template ID, the name, and description.

General information of situation template

Then you add the batch-based trigger from the scenario and refine it with conditions. For our use case we simply add a date filter for the next three days.

Condition for situation detection

Now we add the texts that describe the situation for the end user. The situation title and description are used in various places, for example, in My Situations ‚Äì Extended app, in cards on Fiori launchpad home, and in notifications. We define the title and only use variables to the flight for describing the situation. If we choose to send one notification per situation instance, the same texts are used. The public text My first situation. is added for email notifications (not visible in screenshot).

Situation description for end users

Select Apply.

In the next step we define when the periodical check is scheduled. We define a time zone, a repeat type and interval, and add a start time when the batch is supposed to be scheduled. In the example below, the batch is scheduled every day at 1 am.

Batch-job scheduling

Then we need to define who will be informed about situations. We want to alert users that belong to one or more teams that are responsible for a certain business scope which is expressed by the team category. We use the demo category SITDEMO. Without setting any further filters, all members of the teams belonging to the category would be informed about flights being scheduled within the next three days.

Inform team members about situations

Select Create and your template is complete.

Manage Teams and Responsibilities

Responsibility Management defines who is informed about the situation. Let‚Äôs create a simple team and add yourself as a team member.

Open the app Manage Teams and Responsibilities.

Create a new team and enter general data that describes the team: the name (that is also used as global ID), the description, and the type. The type is a sub-group of the team category. Also ensure that you set the status to enabled.

Define a responsible team

Then you add the team members that will be informed about the situations. For the minimal configuration you just add yourself as member.

Members of responsible team

Create the team and log-off as Business Process Configuration Expert.

Log-in as Business Configuration Specialist.

Situation Handling Demo

You can use the data of the Situation Handling Demo app to create a situation. Just open the app and check if the table is already populated with flight data. If not, choose Generate New Data.

Situation Handling Demo app

Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended

Now you create a situation type from the template that will trigger the situation. Usually, types would be further refined or would be a bundle of variants to reflect specific usage. For example, the logic of a template refers to multiple types which address specific sales regions and therefore need specific adjustments in the condition section. In our sample case we simply use the logic of the template as is.

Open the Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended app.

Create a new situation type from the template My First Template. Set the status to enabled and save it.

General information of situation type

On top of the page choose Trigger Batch.

Trigger the batch-job schedule for a situation type

 

Batch-job feedback

In the dialog select Manage Instances. You might need to wait a moment until the batch-job is finalized and refresh the page. Then you see the list of detected situations, that is all flights that are scheduled within the next three days. As a reference you see the semantic keys that you defined within the situation object structure.

List of situation instances in the Manage Situation Types ‚Äì Extended app

Log-off as Business Process Specialist.

My Situations ‚Äì Extended

In the My Situation ‚Äì Extended app the users see all situations in their area of responsibility.

Log-in with the user you added as team member in the Manage Teams and Responsibilities app.

Open the My Situation ‚Äì Extended  app.

In the left navigation pane select the scenario My First Situation Scenario. The list shows all situations that were detected by the type My First Situation Type. The title My First Situation is the same for all instances. In the description you see the reference to the detected flight, for example, SQ 0160 13.12.2025.

Additionally, you see the new situations indicated next to the notification bell.

List of situations in the My Situations ‚Äì Extended app

When you select a situation, for example in the list page of the My Situation ‚Äì Extended app or from the notifications, you go to the situation details page. As the situation description is all we defined, there is no further information to see.

Situation details page in the My Situations ‚Äì Extended app

You have created your first situations with the minimal configuration. And you have learned which minimal ingredients you need and how they work together.

Next Steps

For further guidance, I recommend reading the following blog posts:

  • Define the optimal information for the end user: Configure the layout of My Situations ‚Äì Extended.
  • Deep dive into the concept of reusability: The Power of Reuse - Custom Situation Configuration.
  • Explore enhanced configuration options: Custom Situation Cases: Configure Your Own Use Cases.

You find many more blog posts in the Best Practices section of Intelligent Situation Handling in the SAP Community. And you can visit SAP Help for further guidance on Situation Handling.

entry.title: Navigate SAP Fiori launchpad with Ease: Launch Apps via Transaction Codes
entry.content:
Overview

We have introduced an innovative feature in the SAP Fiori launchpad offering a swift and efficient way to navigate to applications using transaction codes**.

Users can now perform quick search on transaction code with instant navigation to the corresponding application.

Seamless In-Place and Ex-Place Navigation

  • In-Place Launch: If you have access to a role-based app, simply enter /n followed by the transaction code to launch it in the same browser tab. 

  • Ex-Place Launch: For opening apps in a new browser tab, use /o followed by the transaction code. 

  • Navigation to Start Page: Easily return to the start page with /n, or open it in a new tab with /o.

Key Benefits

  • Instant App Access: Accelerate your workflow with immediate app navigation.
  • Enhanced User Experience: Business users enjoy an empowering and intuitive navigation experience.
  • Familiarity for SAP GUI Users: Mimics the classic navigation style for those accustomed to transaction codes in SAP GUI.

Initial Release Restrictions

Please note that some restrictions apply to this feature in its initial release. For detailed information, refer to SAP Note 3687260.

Feature Release Horizon

This feature is included in version 2602 across various platforms:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Official Documentation
  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment: Official Documentation (Coming Soon)
  • SAP Integrated Business Planning: Official Documentation
Experience the power of seamless navigation and user empowerment while keeping your workflows efficient and intuitive with this cutting-edge feature!

** Discovering Transaction Codes for applications

Some of the ways to identify the transaction code corresponding to an application include:

1. Access the  Fiori reference library , typically for SAP Fiori and SAP GUI applications the  App ID information would correspond to the transaction code.

2. Navigate to an application by other means such as clicking on the tile and invoke the About dialog via User menu to find the transaction code.

Feel free to share any additional shortcuts or cheat sheets you may have in the comments section!

  2. ÊùÉÈôêÁöÑÊõ¥Â§ßÁÅµÊ¥ªÊÄßÔºöÁõ¥Êé•Áªô‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤ÂàÜÈÖçIAMÂ∫îÁî®

 

 

‰∏Ä„ÄÅÊï∞ÊçÆËøÅÁßª

1. Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÔºöExplore Migration Objects

         Âú®Cloud ERPÊï∞ÊçÆËøÅÁßªÈ¢ÜÂüüÔºåÁé∞Âú®Â∑≤ÁªèÊúâË∂ÖËøá200‰∏™ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°„ÄÇËôΩÁÑ∂Êàë‰ª¨ËÉΩÂ§üÂú®ÊØè‰∏™ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÁöÑËØ¥ÊòéÊñáÊ°£‰∏≠Êü•Âà∞ËØ•ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÊòØÂê¶ÊúâÂâçÂ∫è‰æùËµñÁöÑÂØπË±°Ôºå‰ΩÜÂú®Â¶ÇÊ≠§Â§öÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ‰∏ãÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰∏ÄÁõ¥Áº∫Â∞ë‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂèØËßÜÂåñÁöÑÁïåÈù¢ÔºåËÉΩÂ§üËÆ©Êàë‰ª¨Âú®È°πÁõÆÂÆûÊñΩËøáÁ®ã‰∏≠Êõ¥Âø´ÈÄüÂú∞ÁúãÂà∞ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑ‰æùËµñÂÖ≥Á≥ª„ÄÇ

         Áé∞Âú®Êàë‰ª¨Êé®Âá∫‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ®Êñ∞ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®ÔºöExplore Migration Objects„ÄÇÈÄöËøáËØ•Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈÄöËøáÂõæÂΩ¢ÂåñÁöÑÊñπÂºèÊòæÁ§∫Êüê‰∏™ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÊúâÂì™‰∫õÂâçÂ∫è‰æùËµñÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°„ÄÇÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂõæÊâÄÁ§∫ÔºåÂ¶ÇÊûúÊàë‰ª¨ÊÉ≥Ë¶ÅÂØºÂÖ•‚Äú‰∫ßÂìÅ-ÊåâÊñ∞ÁªÑÁªáÁ∫ßÂà´Êâ©Â±ïÁé∞ÊúâËÆ∞ÂΩï‚ÄùÔºåÂÆÉÁöÑÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÂâçÂ∫èÂØπË±°‰ºöÁî®Ê©ôËâ≤ÁöÑÂÆûÁ∫øÊòæÁ§∫ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÂøÖÈ°ªÂÖàÂØºÂÖ•ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°‚Äú‰∫ßÂìÅ‚Äù„ÄÇÂÆÉÁöÑÂèØÈÄâÁöÑÂâçÂ∫èÂØπË±°‰ºöÁî®ÁÅ∞Ëâ≤ÁöÑËôöÁ∫øÊòæÁ§∫Ôºå‚ÄúÂà©Ê∂¶‰∏≠ÂøÉ‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÁîü‰∫ß‰æõÂ∫îÂå∫‚ÄùÊòØÂÆÉÁöÑ‰∏§‰∏™ÈùûÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÂâçÂ∫èÂØπË±°„ÄÇ

         Ëøô‰∏™Â∫îÁî®ÂèØ‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©Êàë‰ª¨Âú®È°πÁõÆÈò∂ÊÆµÊõ¥Êñπ‰æøÂíåÂáÜÁ°ÆÂú∞Á°ÆÂÆöËøÅÁßªËåÉÂõ¥„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂú®ÂõæÂΩ¢ÁïåÈù¢‰∏äÔºå‰Ω†‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÁÇπÂáª‰æùËµñÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÔºåÊâ©Â±ïÊòæÁ§∫‰∏éÂÆÉÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°„ÄÇÂõæÂΩ¢ÁïåÈù¢ÂèØ‰ª•ÈöèÊÑèÊâ©Â±ï„ÄÇ

 

Èô§‰∫ÜÊåâÁÖßËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°Êü•ÊâæÔºåËøô‰∏™Â∫îÁî®‰πüÊîØÊåÅÊåâÁÖßËåÉÂõ¥È°πÁõÆÔºàScope ItemÔºâÊü•Êâæ„ÄÇÂèØ‰ª•Êü•ÊâæÊüê‰∏™ËåÉÂõ¥È°πÁõÆ‰∏ãÊúâÂì™‰∫õÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°„ÄÇÊØîÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂõæ‰∏æ‰æãÔºåÊàëÊÉ≥Êü•ÊâæËåÉÂõ¥È°πÁõÆBMDÔºàÈááË¥≠ÂêàÂêåÔºâÁâµÊ∂âÂà∞Âì™‰∫õËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÔºåÊàë‰πüÂèØ‰ª•ÊâæÂá∫Ëøô‰∏™‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÁî®ÂõæÂΩ¢ÂåñÁöÑÊñπÂºèÊòæÁ§∫Ôºö

 

 

ÊúÄÂêéÔºåËØ¥Êòé‰∏Ä‰∏ã‰ΩìÈ™åËØ•Â∫îÁî®ÈúÄË¶ÅÂàÜÈÖç‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïData Migration ‚Äì CockpitÔºàSAP_CA_BC_MIG_PCÔºâ„ÄÇ

 

2. 2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÁöÑÂèòÂåñ

ÂÖ≥‰∫é2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ËøÅÁßªÂØπË±°ÁöÑÂèòÂåñÔºåÊØîÂ¶ÇÊñ∞Â¢ûÁöÑÂØπË±°„ÄÅÊõ¥ÊîπÁöÑÂØπË±°„ÄÅÂà†Èô§ÁöÑÂØπË±°Á≠âÔºåËØ•‰ø°ÊÅØÂ∑≤ÁªèÂèëÂ∏ÉÂú®SAP Help PortalÔºåÂÖ∑‰ΩìÂèØÈÄöËøá‰ª•‰∏ãÈìæÊé•Êü•ÁúãÔºö

ÁâàÊú¨ 2602 ÁöÑÊõ¥ÊîπÊ¶ÇËßà | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûªÔºö‰æõÂ∫îÈìæÁÆ°ÁêÜÂíåË¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜ
entry.content:
Âú®Êú¨ÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢‰∏≠ÔºåÊàëÂ∞Ü‰ºöÈáçÁÇπÂ±ïÁ§∫Âú® SAP Cloud ERP (SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602ÁâàÊú¨ÂΩì‰∏≠‰æõÂ∫îÈìæÁÆ°ÁêÜÂíåË¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜÊùøÂùóÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑÊñ∞Â¢ûÂäüËÉΩÔºåÂ∞Ü‰ºöË¶ÜÁõñ‰ª•‰∏ãËØùÈ¢òÂÜÖÂÆπÔºö 

  • ‰æõÂ∫îÈìæÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºöÁâ©ÊµÅË∑®‰∏ªÈ¢ò„ÄÅËÆ¢ÂçïÊâøËØ∫„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠òÂàÜÊûê‰∏éÊéßÂà∂„ÄÅ‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜÁ≠â
  • Ë¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºöË¥®ÈáèËÆ°Âàí„ÄÅË¥®ÈáèÊ£ÄÈ™å„ÄÅË¥®ÈáèÊîπËøõÁ≠â

Ê≠§Â§ñÔºåÊúâÂÖ≥ËøêËæìÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰ª•ÂèäÊõ¥Â§ö‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÂÜÖÂÆπËØ∑Êü•ÁúãÂØπÂ∫î‰∏ìÈ¢òÂçöÂÆ¢„ÄÇ

 

‰æõÂ∫îÈìæÁÆ°ÁêÜ 

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ1ÔºöÔºâÁâ©ÊµÅË∑®‰∏ªÈ¢ò ‚Äì Â§ÑÁêÜÂçïÂÖÉ

Âú® SAP Cloud ERPÔºàSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionÔºâ2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠ÔºåÁâ©ÊµÅË∑®‰∏ªÈ¢òÊùøÂùóÁöÑÂ§ÑÁêÜÂçïÂÖÉÔºàHandling UnitÔºâÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÈÖçÁΩÆËøõË°å‰∫ÜÊúØËØ≠Ê†áÂáÜÂåñ‰ºòÂåñ„ÄÇÈíàÂØπÂ§ÑÁêÜÂçïÂÖÉ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑ Serial Shipping Container CodesÔºàSSCCÔºâ ÁºñÁ†ÅÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÁïåÈù¢ÂíåÊñáÊ°£‰∏≠ÂéüÂÖàÁöÑ ‚ÄúILN Âü∫Á°ÄÂè∑‚Äù Â∑≤Áªü‰∏ÄÊõ¥Êñ∞‰∏∫ ‚ÄúGS1 ÂÖ¨Âè∏ÂâçÁºÄ‚ÄùÔºå‰∏éÂΩìÂâç GS1 ÂõΩÈôÖÊ†áÂáÜ‰øùÊåÅ‰∏ÄËá¥„ÄÇËøô‰∏ÄË∞ÉÊï¥Ë¶ÜÁõñ‰∫ÜÊåâÂ∑•ÂéÇ/Â∫ìÂ≠òÂú∞ÁÇπÂèäÊåâ‰ªìÂ∫ìÂè∑Áª¥Êä§ SSCC ÁºñÁ†ÅÁöÑÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÈÖçÁΩÆÊ¥ªÂä®„ÄÇ

ÈúÄË¶ÅËØ¥ÊòéÁöÑÊòØÔºåÊú¨Ê¨°Êõ¥Êñ∞‰ªÖÊ∂âÂèäÊúØËØ≠Â±ÇÈù¢‰ºòÂåñÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÁîüÊàêÈÄªËæëÂèäÁé∞Êúâ‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ã‰øùÊåÅ‰∏çÂèò„ÄÇÈÄöËøáÊõ¥Âä†Ê∏ÖÊô∞„ÄÅÊ†áÂáÜÂåñÁöÑÂëΩÂêçÊñπÂºèÔºåÁî®Êà∑Âú®ÈÖçÁΩÆÂíåÁêÜËß£ SSCC ÁªìÊûÑÊó∂Êõ¥Âä†Áõ¥ËßÇÔºåÊúâÂä©‰∫éÈôç‰ΩéÊ≤üÈÄöÂÅèÂ∑ÆÔºåÂπ∂ÊèêÂçáË∑®Âå∫Âüü„ÄÅË∑®ÁªÑÁªáÁÆ°ÁêÜÂèäÂêéÁª≠Á≥ªÁªüÊâ©Â±ïÂíåÂêàËßÑÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑÂèØÁª¥Êä§ÊÄß„ÄÇ

 Ê∂âÂèäÊ≠§È°πÊõ¥Êñ∞ÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÈ°πÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö

  • SSCUI: 103441 Maintain SSCC Generation for each Plant/Storage Location ÈíàÂØπÊØè‰∏™Â∑•ÂéÇ/Â≠òÂÇ®Âú∞ÁÇπÁª¥Êä§Ë£ÖËøêÈõÜË£ÖÁÆ±Â∫èÂàóÁ†ÅÁîüÊàê

 

  • SSCUI: 102843 Maintain SSCC Generation for each Warehouse Number Áª¥Êä§ÊØè‰ªìÂ∫ìÁºñÂè∑ÁöÑ SSCC ÁîüÊàê

 

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ2ÔºöÔºâÁâ©ÊµÅË∑®‰∏ªÈ¢ò ‚Äì Â∫èÂàóÂè∑ÁÆ°ÁêÜ

Âú®Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑ÁÆ°ÁêÜÔºàSerial Number ManagementÔºâÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÁªìÊûÑËøõË°å‰∫Ü‰ºòÂåñ„ÄÇÂéüÂÖàÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÊ¥ªÂä® ‚ÄúÂÆö‰πâÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑ÈÖçÁΩÆÊñá‰ª∂ÔºàDefine Serial Number Profiles, 103636Ôºâ‚Äù Â∑≤‰ªé ‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜ ‚Üí ‰ªìÂ∫ì‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆ ‚Üí ‰ªìÂ∫ìÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑ËÆæÁΩÆ ËøÅÁßªËá≥Êñ∞ÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑ Logistics ‚Üí Serial Number Management ‚Üí Â∏∏ËßÑËÆæÁΩÆ ËøõË°åÁª¥Êä§„ÄÇ

ÈÄöËøáÂ∞Ü‰∏éÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑ÁÆ°ÁêÜÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÈõÜ‰∏≠Âà∞Âêå‰∏ÄËäÇÁÇπÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÁªìÊûÑÊõ¥Âä†Ê∏ÖÊô∞Áªü‰∏ÄÔºåÂÆ¢Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Ë∑®‰∏öÂä°Âú∫ÊôØÔºàÂ¶Ç‰ªìÂ∫ì„ÄÅÁîü‰∫ßÊàñÈîÄÂîÆÊµÅÁ®ãÔºâ‰∏≠ÈõÜ‰∏≠ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑Á≠ñÁï•„ÄÇËøô‰∏ç‰ªÖÊèêÂçá‰∫ÜÈÖçÁΩÆÁöÑ‰∏ÄËá¥ÊÄßÔºå‰πüÂ¢ûÂº∫‰∫ÜÊï¥‰ΩìÁÆ°ÁêÜÊïàÁéáÔºå‰ΩøÂ∫èÂàóÂè∑ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊõ¥Áõ¥ËßÇ„ÄÅÊòìÁª¥Êä§„ÄÇ

Â§áÊ≥®Ôºö‰ª•‰∏äÊà™ÂõæÊù•Ëá™ÂÜÖÈÉ®ÊµãËØïÁ≥ªÁªüConfigure Your Solution - SSCUIË∑ØÂæÑÔºåËã•‰∏∫3SL LandscapeÔºåËØ∑ÊêúÁ¥¢Configuration Activity: Define Serial Number Profiles 103636ÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑ„ÄÇ

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ3ÔºöÔºâËÆ¢ÂçïÊâøËØ∫ ‚Äì ‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®ÊÄßÊòæÁ§∫‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§ÊåáÁ§∫

Âú® SAP Cloud ERPÔºàSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public EditionÔºâ2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®ÊÄßÊòæÁ§∫ÔºàDisplay Product AvailabilityÔºâÂ∫îÁî®Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§ÔºàSupply ProtectionÔºåSUPÔºâ ÂõæÊ†áÔºåÁî®‰∫éÁõ¥ËßÇÊ†áËØÜÂΩìÂâçÊòæÁ§∫ÁöÑÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÊòØÂê¶Âèó SUP ÈÖçÁΩÆÂΩ±Âìç„ÄÇÂõæÊ†áÁõ¥Êé•ÊòæÁ§∫Âú®‰∫ßÂìÅÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÊóÅÔºåÂΩìÂú®Ê£ÄÊü•ËåÉÂõ¥ÔºàScope of CheckÔºâÈÖçÁΩÆ‰∏≠ÂêØÁî®‚ÄúÈíàÂØπÁâπÂÆöÂá≠ËØÅÁ±ªÂûãÂêØÁî®‰æõÂ∫î‰øùÊä§‚ÄùÔºå‰∏îÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∑≤ÈÖçÁΩÆ SUP Êó∂ÔºåÊòæÁ§∫ÁöÑÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÂèØËÉΩ‰∏éÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢ÂçïÂàõÂª∫Êó∂Áï•ÊúâÂ∑ÆÂºÇÔºåÂõ†‰∏∫Á≥ªÁªü‰ºöÊ†πÊçÆ SUP ËßÑÂàôÂØπ‰ºòÂÖàÂÆ¢Êà∑„ÄÅÊ∏†ÈÅìÊàñ‰∏öÂä°Á±ªÂûãËøõË°å‰øùÊä§ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ

SUP ÂõæÊ†áÂú®ÁïåÈù¢‰∏äÂèØÂëàÁé∞‰∏§ÁßçÁä∂ÊÄÅÔºöÁÅ∞Ëâ≤Ë°®Á§∫ÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÊú™ÂèóÂà∞ SUP ÂΩ±ÂìçÔºåËìùËâ≤Ë°®Á§∫ÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÂèØËÉΩÂ∑≤Ê†πÊçÆ SUP ÈÖçÁΩÆË∞ÉÊï¥„ÄÇÈÄöËøáËøô‰∏ÄÂ¢ûÂº∫ÂäüËÉΩÔºåÁî®Êà∑ÂèØ‰ª•Êõ¥ÈÄèÊòéÂú∞ÁêÜËß£ÂèØÁî®Êï∞ÈáèÁöÑÊù•Ê∫ê‰∏éËÆ°ÁÆóÈÄªËæëÔºåÂáèÂ∞ëÂõ† SUP ËßÑÂàô‰∫ßÁîüÁöÑÁñëÊÉëÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊèêÂçá SUP ÈÖçÁΩÆÂú®‰∏öÂä°ËøêËê•‰∏≠ÁöÑÂèØËß£ÈáäÊÄß‰∏éÂèØÊéßÊÄß„ÄÇÈúÄË¶ÅÊ≥®ÊÑèÁöÑÊòØÔºåSUP ÂäüËÉΩÂ±û‰∫é‰ªòË¥π Scope Item 1JWÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂÆ¢Êà∑ÊåâÈúÄË¥≠‰π∞Âπ∂ÊøÄÊ¥ªÊâçËÉΩ‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÇ

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ4ÔºöÔºâÂ∫ìÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜ ‚Äì È¢ÑÁïô

Âú®Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÈ¢ÑÁïôÁõ∏ÂÖ≥ÊµÅÁ®ãÂæóÂà∞‰∫ÜËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•Â¢ûÂº∫„ÄÇÁî®Êà∑Áé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•Âú® ‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÈ¢ÑÁïôÈ°πÁõÆÔºàManage Reservation ItemsÔºâ‚Äù Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠ÔºåÁõ¥Êé•Âü∫‰∫éÈ¢ÑÁïôÂàõÂª∫Â∫ìÂ≠òËΩ¨ÂÇ®ËøáË¥¶ÔºàÁßªÂä®Á±ªÂûã 311Ôºâ„ÄÇÊâßË°åËΩ¨ÂÇ®Êó∂ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªü‰ºöËá™Âä®Ë∑≥ËΩ¨Ëá≥ ‚ÄúÁÆ°ÁêÜÈ¢ÑÁïôÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÔºàManage Material Documents for ReservationsÔºâ‚Äù Â∫îÁî®ÂÆåÊàêËøáË¥¶Êìç‰ΩúÔºåËøáË¥¶ÊàêÂäüÂêéËá™Âä®ÁîüÊàê‰∏§Êù°Áâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÊòéÁªÜÔºö‰∏ÄÊù°ÂØπÂ∫îÂèëË¥ßÔºàGoods IssueÔºâÔºåÂè¶‰∏ÄÊù°ÂØπÂ∫îÊî∂Ë¥ßÔºàGoods ReceiptÔºâ„ÄÇ

Ëøô‰∏ÄÂ¢ûÂº∫‰ΩøÂ∫ìÂ≠òËΩ¨ÂÇ®‰∏öÂä°‰∏éÈ¢ÑÁïôÁÆ°ÁêÜÊõ¥Âä†Á¥ßÂØÜË°îÊé•ÔºåÂáèÂ∞ëÊâãÂä®ÂàáÊç¢ÂíåÈáçÂ§çÂΩïÂÖ•Êìç‰ΩúÔºåÊèêÂçáÊìç‰ΩúÊïàÁéáÔºåÂêåÊó∂Â¢ûÂº∫‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÁöÑÂèØËøΩÊ∫ØÊÄßÔºå‰∏∫Áî®Êà∑Êèê‰æõÊõ¥ÊµÅÁïÖÁöÑÂ∫ìÂ≠òÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰ΩìÈ™å„ÄÇ

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ5ÔºöÔºâÂ∫ìÂ≠òÂàÜÊûê‰∏éÊéßÂà∂ ‚Äì Áâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÊ¶ÇËßà

Âú®Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÂ∫ìÂ≠òÂàÜÊûê‰∏éÊéßÂà∂ÊùøÂùóÁöÑ‚ÄúÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÊ¶ÇËßàÔºàMaterial Documents OverviewÔºâ‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂ§öÈ°πÊòæÁ§∫‰ºòÂåñÂäüËÉΩÔºåËøõ‰∏ÄÊ≠•ÊèêÂçáÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÁöÑÂèØËßÜÂåñÂíåÂàÜÊûêËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇÂ∫îÁî®Âú®Êú¨ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûÊèê‰æõ‰∏§ÁßçÂàóË°®ËßÜÂõæÔºöÂπ≥Èù¢ÂàóË°®ÔºàFlat ListÔºâ-ÂèØÊòæÁ§∫Áâ©Êñô„ÄÅÂ∑•ÂéÇ„ÄÅÂ∫ìÂ≠òÂú∞ÁÇπ„ÄÅÁßªÂä®Á±ªÂûã„ÄÅÁâπÊÆäÂ∫ìÂ≠òÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÅÊï∞ÈáèÁ≠âÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂ≠óÊÆµÔºå‰æø‰∫éÂø´ÈÄüÊµèËßàÊ†∏ÂøÉ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºõÂ±ÇÊ¨°ÁªìÊûÑÊ∏ÖÂçïÔºàHierarchical ListÔºâ-ÂàôÊåâÁâ©ÊñôÂíåÂ∑•ÂéÇËøõË°åÂàÜÁªÑÔºåÂ∏ÆÂä©Áî®Êà∑Áõ¥ËßÇ‰∫ÜËß£Áâ©ÊñôÂú®‰∏çÂêåÂ∑•ÂéÇÁöÑÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÂàÜÂ∏É„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÊú¨Â∫îÁî®‰πüÊîØÊåÅÊï∞Èáè‰∏é‰ª∑ÂÄºÁöÑÊ±áÊÄªÊòæÁ§∫ÔºåÊñπ‰æøËøõË°åÂ∫ìÂ≠ò‰∏éË¥¢Âä°ÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇ

ÂÄüÂä©Ëøô‰∫õÂ¢ûÂº∫ÂäüËÉΩÔºåÁî®Êà∑‰∏ç‰ªÖÂèØ‰ª•Âø´ÈÄüÊü•ÁúãÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÊòéÁªÜÔºåËøòËÉΩËΩªÊùæËé∑ÂèñÊâÄÈÄâÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÁöÑËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ø°ÊÅØÔºå‰ªéËÄåÊòæËëóÊèêÂçáÁâ©ÊñôÂá≠ËØÅÁÆ°ÁêÜÁöÑÊïàÁéáÂíåÊï∞ÊçÆÂèØËØªÊÄß„ÄÇ

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ6ÔºöÔºâ‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜ ‚Äì Á≤æÁÆÄÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄË¥ßÊµÅÁ®ãÔºàÂåÖË£ÖÊùêÊñôÂíåËµ†ÂìÅÈÄÄÂõûÊîØÊåÅÔºâ

Âú®Êú¨Ê¨°ÁâàÊú¨Êõ¥Êñ∞‰∏≠ÔºåÁ≤æÁÆÄÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄË¥ßÊµÅÁ®ãÔºàLean Customer ReturnsÔºâÊñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂØπÂåÖË£ÖÊùêÊñôÂèäÈöè‰∫ßÂìÅÈôÑËµ†ÂÖçË¥πÁâ©ÂìÅÁöÑÈÄÄË¥ßÊîØÊåÅ„ÄÇÈÄöËøáËøô‰∏ÄÂäüËÉΩÔºåÁî®Êà∑Âú®Â§ÑÁêÜÈÄÄË¥ßÊó∂Êó†ÈúÄËøõË°åÂ∫ìÂ≠òÊ£ÄÈ™åÔºåÂç≥ÂèØÂ∞ÜÂåÖË£ÖÊùêÊñôÊàñÂÖçË¥πÈôÑËµ†ÂìÅÁõ¥Êé•ÈÄÄÂõûÔºå‰ªéËÄåÁÆÄÂåñÊìç‰ΩúÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊù•ËØ¥ÔºåÁî®Êà∑Âú®ÈîÄÂîÆÊ®°Âùó‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫Á≤æÁÆÄÈÄÄË¥ßÂçïÔºàLean Returns OrderÔºâÂêéÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜËá™Âä®ÁîüÊàêÈÄÄË¥ß‰∫§Ë¥ßÂçïÔºàReturns DeliveryÔºâÔºåËØ•‰∫§Ë¥ßÂçïÂú®‰ªìÂ∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰∏≠‰Ωú‰∏∫ÂÖ•Â∫ì‰∫§Ë¥ßÂçïÊé•Êî∂ÔºåÈÄÄÂõûÁâ©ÂìÅÂèØÁõ¥Êé•ÂÖ•Â∫ì‰∏äÊû∂ÔºåÊó†ÈúÄÈ¢ùÂ§ñË¥®ÈáèÊ£ÄÈ™å„ÄÇÊ≠§ÂäüËÉΩÂáèÂ∞ë‰∫Ü‰∫∫Â∑•Êìç‰ΩúÁéØËäÇÔºåÊèêÂçá‰ªìÂÇ®Â§ÑÁêÜÊïàÁéáÔºåÂêåÊó∂Á°Æ‰øùÈÄÄÂõûÁâ©ÊñôËÉΩÂ§üÂø´ÈÄü„ÄÅÂáÜÁ°ÆÂú∞ÂÖ•Â∫ìÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÄÇ

 

 

 

Ë¥®ÈáèÁÆ°ÁêÜ

 

Ôºà‰∫ÆÁÇπ7ÔºöÔºâË¥®ÈáèËÆ°Âàí ‚Äì ÊòæÁ§∫Ë¥®Èáè‰ø°ÊÅØËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºàF2256ÔºâÁªß‰ªªÂ∫îÁî®

SAP_COM_1018 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØ (SAP Cash Application Integration) Âú®2602ÁâàÊú¨Â∑≤Âà†Èô§„ÄÇSAP_COM_0650 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØÔºàÂÖ∑ÊúâÁõ∏ÂêåÂêçÁß∞ SAP Cash Application ÈõÜÊàêÔºâÊòØ SAP_COM_1018 ÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØÁöÑÂêéÁªß„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Âª∫ËÆÆÊÇ®Â∞ΩÂø´ÂàáÊç¢Âà∞ÂêéÁªßÈÄö‰ø°Âú∫ÊôØ (SAP_COM_0650)„ÄÇ

 

„ÄêÂêéÁª≠Â∫îÁî®È°ªÁü•„Äë

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP 2602ÔºàS/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Ôºâ‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûªÔºöÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®
entry.content:
ÊúÄÊñ∞S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÂèëÂ∏ÉÔºå‰∏∫ÂàÜÊûêÂ∏¶Êù•‰∫ÜÂº∫Â§ßÁöÑÂäüËÉΩÂ¢ûÂº∫ÔºåÊó®Âú®ÊèêÂçáÂèØÁî®ÊÄß„ÄÅÁÆÄÂåñÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÁ®ãÂπ∂Êèê‰æõÊõ¥Ê∑±ÂàªÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØü„ÄÇËøô‰∫õÊñ∞ÂäüËÉΩÂØπ‰∫é‰æùËµñÂèäÊó∂ÂáÜÁ°ÆÊï∞ÊçÆÊù•È©±Âä®‰∏öÂä°ÂèëÂ±ïÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°ÂàÜÊûê‰∏ìÂÆ∂„ÄÅË¥¢Âä°Áõ∏ÂÖ≥‰∏öÂä°‰∫∫Âëò‰ª•ÂèäÂÜ≥Á≠ñËÄÖÂ∞§‰∏∫ÈáçË¶Å„ÄÇ‰∏ãÈù¢Êàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜÊ∑±ÂÖ•Êé¢ËÆ®Ëøô‰∏™ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÈáçË¶ÅÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇ

  • Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÔºöÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÔºàÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Ôºâ

Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÔºöÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÔºàÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Ôºâ

Ê≠§Ê¨°ÂèëÂ∏ÉÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂ§ß‰∫ÆÁÇπÊòØÂÖ®Êñ∞ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®Â∫îÁî®ÔºåÊòØÊóßÁâàÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÂΩïÂàÜÊûêÂô®ÁöÑÂêéÁªßÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨ÁªèËøáÈáçÊñ∞ËÆæËÆ°ÔºåÊ∑±Â∫¶ÈõÜÊàê‰∫ÜÂº∫Â§ßÁöÑÂ§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÔºàMultidimensional AnalysisÔºâÊ°ÜÊû∂Ôºå‰∏∫Ë¥¢Âä°‰∏öÂä°‰∫∫ÂëòÊèê‰æõÂèØ‰∫§‰∫í„ÄÅÂèØËøΩÊ∫Ø„ÄÅÂèØÊé¢Á¥¢ÁöÑÊó•ËÆ∞Ë¥¶ÂàÜÊûêÂ∑•‰ΩúÂè∞„ÄÇÂÆÉ‰∏çÂÜçÊòØÈùôÊÄÅÊä•Ë°®ÔºåËÄåÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊîØÊåÅÁÅµÊ¥ªÂàáÁâá„ÄÅÂä®ÊÄÅÂàÜÁªÑ‰∏éÊ∑±ÂÖ•‰∏ãÈíªÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÁéØÂ¢ÉÔºåÊòæËëóÊèêÂçáÂØπÂ§çÊùÇË¥¢Âä°ÂÖ≥Á≥ª‰∏éÂºÇÂ∏∏Ê®°ÂºèÁöÑÂèëÁé∞ËÉΩÂäõ„ÄÇ

‰∫ÆÁÇπÂäüËÉΩÂåÖÂê´Ôºö

  • Â§öÁª¥ÂàÜÊûêÂéüÁîüÈõÜÊàêÔºöÊ∑±Â∫¶Âà©Áî® Multidimensional Analysis Ê°ÜÊû∂ÔºåÊîØÊåÅ‰ªªÊÑèÁª¥Â∫¶ÁöÑÂàáÁâá„ÄÅÁ≠õÈÄâ‰∏éËÅöÂêàÔºå‰ΩøÂ§çÊùÇÂàÜÊûêÂú®Â∫îÁî®ÂÜÖÂç≥ÂèØÂÆåÊàê„ÄÇ
  • UI5 ÁªÑ‰ª∂‰∏éËÆ°ÁÆóÂ∫¶ÈáèÂØπËØùÊ°ÜÔºöÂÜÖÁΩÆ UI5 ‰∫§‰∫íÁªÑ‰ª∂‰∏éËÆ°ÁÆóÂ∫¶ÈáèÂØπËØùÊ°ÜÔºåÁî®Êà∑ÂèØÂú®Â∫îÁî®ÂÜÖÂç≥Êó∂ÂàõÂª∫Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâËÆ°ÁÆóÂ∫¶ÈáèÔºåÊó†ÈúÄÂàáÊç¢Â∑•ÂÖ∑ÔºåÊñπ‰æøÂõûÁ≠îÂ§çÊùÇË¥¢Âä°ÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ
  • ÁÅµÊ¥ªÁª¥Â∫¶‰∏éÈÄèËßÜÂàÜÊûêÔºöÊîØÊåÅÊåâÂàÜÁ±ªË¥¶ÔºàLedgerÔºâ„ÄÅÂÖ¨Âè∏‰ª£Á†Å„ÄÅ‰ºöËÆ°Âπ¥Â∫¶/ÊúüÈó¥ÔºàFiscal Year/PeriodÔºâ„ÄÅÊÄªË¥¶ÁßëÁõÆÔºàG/L AccountÔºâÁ≠â‰ªªÊÑèÁª¥Â∫¶ÁªÑÂêàÊü•ÁúãÔºõÂπ∂ÂèØÂú®Ë°å/ÂàóÂ±ÇÈù¢ÈíªÂèñÔºå‰ª•ÈÄèËßÜË°®ÔºàpivotÔºâÊñπÂºè‰∫§ÂèâÊØîËæÉ‰∏éÂàáÊç¢Êï∞ÊçÆËßÜÂõæ„ÄÇ

entry.content:
Â§ßÂÆ∂Â•ΩÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Âç≥Â∞ÜËøéÊù• SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 Â§ßÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÊõ¥Êñ∞„ÄÇÂú®Êú¨ÁØáÂçöÂÆ¢‰∏≠ÔºåÊàëÂ∞Ü‰ºöÈáçÁÇπÂ±ïÁ§∫Âú® SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 ÂΩì‰∏≠ÂèØÊãìÂ±ïÊÄßÈÉ®ÂàÜÁöÑ‰∫ÆÁÇπÊõ¥Êñ∞ÂÜÖÂÆπ„ÄÇ

API ÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂ¢ûÂº∫‰∏éÂèòÊõ¥

APIÂèØ‰ª•Â∏ÆÂä©Êàë‰ª¨ÂÆûÁé∞Á≥ªÁªüÈó¥ÁöÑÈõÜÊàê„ÄÇÂú®2602ÁâàÊú¨ÔºåÂ§ö‰∏™APIÈÉΩËøéÊù•‰∫ÜÊòæËëóÁöÑÂèòÊõ¥Ôºö

  • ÊàêÊú¨ÁéáAPI (Cost Rate API)ÔºöODATA V2ÁâàÊú¨ÁöÑÊàêÊú¨ÁéáAPIÂ∑≤Ë¢´Ê†áËÆ∞‰∏∫‚ÄúÂºÉÁî®‚ÄùÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂú®2702ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ê≠£ÂºèÂÅúÁî®„ÄÇÂèñËÄå‰ª£‰πãÁöÑÊòØÂäüËÉΩÊõ¥Âº∫ÁöÑODATA V4ÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÂª∫ËÆÆÁî®Êà∑Â∞ΩÂø´ËøÅÁßªÂà∞Êñ∞ÁöÑAPI„ÄÇ
  • ÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄË¥ß„ÄÅË¥∑È°π/ÂÄüÈ°πÂá≠ËØÅËØ∑Ê±ÇAPIÔºöËøôÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈúÄË¶ÅÁ´ãÂç≥ÂÖ≥Ê≥®ÁöÑÂÖ≥ÈîÆÂèòÊõ¥„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÊèêÂçáÊï∞ÊçÆÂÆåÊï¥ÊÄßÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂØπÂÆ¢Êà∑ÈÄÄË¥ß (A2X) OData V4 APIÁ≠âÁõ∏ÂÖ≥APIÂä†Âº∫‰∫ÜÊï∞ÊçÆÊ†°È™å„ÄÇÁé∞Âú®ÔºåAPIÂ∞ÜÈôêÂà∂Âú®ÂàõÂª∫Âá≠ËØÅÊó∂ÂêëÊüê‰∫õÂ≠óÊÆµ‰º†ÈÄíÂàùÂßãÂÄºÔºàÁ©∫ÂÄºÔºâÔºå‰ª•ÈÅøÂÖçÂêéÁ´ØÈÄªËæëË¶ÜÁõñÂèØËÉΩÂØºËá¥ÁöÑÊ∑∑Ê∑ÜÂíå‰∏ç‰∏ÄËá¥„ÄÇ
  • ÂïÜ‰∏öÈ°πÁõÆAPIÔºö‰∏∫Èò≤Ê≠¢Êï∞ÊçÆ‰∏ç‰∏ÄËá¥ÔºåÂΩìËµÑÊ∫ê‰æõÂ∫îÂ≠òÂú®Êú™ÊâπÂáÜÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥ËÆ∞ÂΩïÊó∂ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªüÂ∞ÜÈôêÂà∂ÈÄöËøáAPIÂà†Èô§ËØ•ËµÑÊ∫ê‰æõÂ∫î„ÄÇ

ÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑Êâ©Â±ïÊÄßÂ¢ûÂº∫

ÂØπ‰∫é‰∏öÂä°‰∏ìÂÆ∂ÂíåÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑ËÄåË®ÄÔºå2602ÁâàÊú¨Âú®Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµÊñπÈù¢Â∏¶Êù•‰∫ÜÂá†ÁÇπÈáçË¶ÅÁöÑÊèêÂçáÔºö

  • Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµÊï∞ÊçÆÊµÅÊâìÈÄöÔºö
    • ‰ªé‰∫ßÂìÅ‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆÂà∞ÈîÄÂîÆÂá≠ËØÅÔºöÁé∞Âú®ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÁÆÄÂçïÁöÑÈÖçÁΩÆÔºåÂÆûÁé∞Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµ‰ªé‰∫ßÂìÅ‰∏ªÊï∞ÊçÆËá™Âä®Â∏¶Âà∞ÈîÄÂîÆÂá≠ËØÅË°åÈ°πÁõÆÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÂÖÅËÆ∏Âú®ÈîÄÂîÆÂá≠ËØÅ‰∏≠‰øÆÊîπ„ÄÇ

    • Èõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπÁª¥Êä§ÔºöÂÖ≥ÈîÆÁî®Êà∑Ê†πÊçÆ‰∏öÂä°ÈúÄÊ±ÇÔºåÂØπ‚ÄúÁª¥Êä§Èõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπ‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ËøõË°åËá™ÂÆö‰πâÂ≠óÊÆµÊãìÂ±ï„ÄÇÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Â≠óÊÆµÂåÖÊã¨ÔºöÈõ∂ÂîÆÁ´ôÁÇπ (Retail Site - RFM_SITE)„ÄÅÁ´ôÁÇπÂïÜÂìÅÁ±ªÂà´ (Site Merchandise Category - RFM_SITEMERCHANDISECATEGORY)„ÄÅÈõ∂ÂîÆ‰æõÂ∫îÁ´ôÁÇπ (Retail Supplying Site - RFM_SITESUPPLYINGSITE)„ÄÅÁ´ôÁÇπÂïÜÂìÅÁ±ªÂà´‰æõÂ∫îÁ´ôÁÇπ (Site Merchandise Category Supplying Site - RFM_SITEMRCHDSCATSUPPLYINGSITE)„ÄÇÊ≠§Â§ñÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÈÄöËøáÂú® SAP Business Application Studio ‰∏≠ÂàõÂª∫ SAPUI5 ÈÄÇÈÖçÈ°πÁõÆÊù•Êâ©Â±ïËØ•Â∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÁöÑÊ∫ê‰ª£Á†ÅÔºåÂπ∂Â∞ÜÂÖ∂ÈÉ®ÁΩ≤Âà∞ÂÖ¨Êúâ‰∫ëÁ≥ªÁªü‰∏ä„ÄÇ

Ê≠§Â§ñÔºå‰πüÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∫õÊñ∞Â¢û‰∏öÂä°Â¢ûÂº∫ÁÇπ„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÂú®2602‰∏≠ÔºåÊñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂÇ¨Ê¨æÈÄöÁü•ÁöÑBAdIÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏Âú®ËøêË°åÊó∂Â∞ÜÂÆ¢Êà∑ÁâπÂÆöÁöÑÂ≠óÊÆµÂ°´ÂÖÖÂà∞FI-CAÂÇ¨Ê¨æÈÄöÁü•‰∏≠ÔºåËøô‰∫õÂ≠óÊÆµÂèØ‰ª•Áõ¥Êé•Âú®ÊâìÂç∞Ë°®Âçï‰∏≠‰ΩøÁî®„ÄÇ

Ëá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°APPÊõ¥Êñ∞

‚ÄúËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°‚ÄùÂ∫îÁî®ÂèëÂ∏É‰∫ÜÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨„ÄÇÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•‰ΩøÁî®Ê≠§Â∫îÁî®ÂàõÂª∫ÂåÖÂê´Â≠óÊÆµ„ÄÅËäÇÁÇπÂíåË°å‰∏∫ÁöÑËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°„ÄÇÂü∫‰∫éÊ≠§Á±ªËá™ÂÆö‰πâ‰∏öÂä°ÂØπË±°ÔºåÊÇ®ÂèØ‰ª•ÁîüÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂåÖÂê´Êï∞ÊçÆÂ∫ìË°®„ÄÅCDS ËßÜÂõæ„ÄÅOData ÊúçÂä°Âíå Fiori Elements Áî®Êà∑ÁïåÈù¢ÔºàUIÔºâÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇËØ•Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÊóßÁâàÊú¨Âü∫‰∫é BOPF Ê°ÜÊû∂ÁîüÊàêÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫èÔºåËÄåÊñ∞ÁâàÊú¨Âàô‰ΩøÁî® RAP Ê°ÜÊû∂„ÄÇËøô‰∏™Êñ∞Â∫îÁî®ÂÖÅËÆ∏ÊÇ®Ê†πÊçÆ Clean Core ÁöÑÂéüÂàôÂºÄÂèë‰∫ëÂ∞±Áª™ÁöÑÂ∫îÁî®Á®ãÂ∫è„ÄÇ

entry.content:

ÈááË¥≠ËÆ¢ÂçïÁöÑÂ∑•‰ΩúÊµÅÊ®°Êãü

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602 ‰∫ÆÁÇπÂâçÁûªÔºö‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå
entry.content:
ÂÜÖÂÆπÊëòË¶Å

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∞ÜÊàê‰∏∫ÂåÖÂê´Áîü‰∫ßÂ∑ÆÂºÇÁöÑ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõ (W0182) ÁöÑÁªß‰ªªÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏ªË¶ÅÁî®‰∫éÊîØÊåÅÈîÄÂîÆ‰ºöËÆ°Âü∫‰∫éÂçï‰∏Ä‰∫ßÂìÅÊàñËÄÖ‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑËøõË°åÂà©Ê∂¶ÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÂ∞ÜÊòØSAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Á≥ªÁªü‰∏ã‰∏Ä‰ª£ÊôÆÈÅç‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®Ê†ºÂºèÔºåÂª∫ËÆÆÂ§ßÂÆ∂Êú™Êù•Â∞ΩÂø´Â∞ÜÁõ∏ÂÖ≥Êä•Ë°®ÂàáÊç¢Ëá≥ÂØπÂ∫îÁöÑÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ

Âú® 2602 ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Ôºå‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫ÜÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂäüËÉΩÔºö

2602ÁâàÊú¨‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûÂäüËÉΩÁöÑËØ¶ÁªÜ‰ªãÁªç

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÂàÜÊûêËßÜÂõæ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®ÁöÑÊØõÂà©Ê¶ÇËßàÈ°µÁ≠æ‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂêåÊúüÈó¥‰∏ä‰∏ÄÂπ¥‚ÄùËßÜÂõæÔºåÁî®‰∫éÊä•ÂëäÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÊØîËæÉÂàÜÊûêÔºåÊîØÊåÅ‰∏ÄÈîÆÂàáÊç¢Êä•Ë°®ÊòæÁ§∫ËßÜÂõæÔºåËäÇÁúÅÊâãÂ∑•Ë∞ÉÊï¥ÊòæÁ§∫ÂèÇÊï∞ÁöÑÊó∂Èó¥„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÁõ∏ÂêåÊúüÈó¥‰∏ä‰∏ÄÂπ¥‚ÄùËßÜÂõæ (Same Period Last Year)ÔºöÊä•ÂëäÊúüÈó¥‰∏é‰∏äÂπ¥Âêå‰∏ÄÊúüÈó¥ÁöÑÊØîËæÉÂàÜÊûê„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÁª¥Â∫¶Â≠óÊÆµ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢û‰∫Ü3‰∏™‚ÄúÁª¥Â∫¶‚ÄùÂ≠óÊÆµÔºö‚ÄúÂèÇËÄÉÂá≠ËØÅÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºå‚ÄúÂ∫ìÂ≠òËØÑ‰º∞Á±ªÂûã‚ÄùÂíå‚Äú‰∏öÂä°‰∫§ÊòìÁ±ªÂûã‚ÄùÔºåÁî®‰∫éÁ≠õÈÄâÂíåÊòæÁ§∫Êä•Ë°®Êï∞ÊçÆ„ÄÇ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûÊîØÊåÅ‚ÄúFC ÂäüËÉΩË¥ßÂ∏Å‚ÄùÁ±ªÂûã„ÄÇÂäüËÉΩË¥ßÂ∏ÅÊòØ‰ºÅ‰∏ö‰∏ªË¶ÅÁªèÊµéÁéØÂ¢ÉÊâÄ‰ΩøÁî®ÁöÑË¥ßÂ∏ÅÔºåÂú®SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠Áî®‰∫éÂπ≥Ë°åË¥ßÂ∏ÅËØÑ‰º∞„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûÊ≥®ÈáäÂäüËÉΩ

ÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÊä•Ë°®Â∫îÁî®ÊôÆÈÅçÊîØÊåÅ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÂêéÁª≠ÈáçÊñ∞ÊâìÂºÄÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÔºåË∞ÉÊï¥Âà∞ÂéüÊúâÊä•Ë°®ÊòæÁ§∫ÂèÇÊï∞ÊâßË°å‰πãÂêéÔºåÊâìÂºÄ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÈù¢ÊùøÔºå‚ÄúÈ°µÈù¢Ê≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÈÉΩ‰ºöËá™Âä®ÊòæÁ§∫„ÄÇ

‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÂàÜ‰∏∫‚ÄúÈ°µÈù¢Ê≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂíå‚ÄúÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä‚Äù‰∏§Á±ªÔºåËØ•ÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅÂØπÊï¥‰∏™Êä•Ë°®È°µÈù¢ÁïôË®ÄÔºå‰πüÊîØÊåÅÂØπÊüê‰∏ÄÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊï∞ÊçÆÊèêÂá∫ÁñëÈóÆÊàñËÄÖÁïôË®ÄÂª∫ËÆÆÂ§çÊ†∏Êï∞ÊçÆÁ≠âÊìç‰ΩúÔºåÁïô‰∏ãÁöÑÊ≥®ÈáäÂèØ‰ª•Áî±ÂÖ∂‰ªñ‰∫∫Ëß£Á≠îÂíåÂõûÂ§çÔºå‰øÉËøõÂíå‰ºòÂåñÂõ¢ÈòüÂçè‰Ωú„ÄÇ‚ÄúÊ≥®Èáä‚ÄùÂäüËÉΩÊîØÊåÅÂêéÁª≠‰øÆÊîπÔºåÊ∑ªÂä†ÂàÜÁ±ªÔºåÁä∂ÊÄÅÂíåÊ†áÁ≠æÁ≠â‰ø°ÊÅØÔºåÊñπ‰æøÂêéÁª≠Ê£ÄÁ¥¢„ÄÇ

È°µÈù¢Ê≥®ÈáäÔºö

 

ÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÔºö

 

Ë¶ÅÊ∑ªÂä†ÊàñËÄÖÊòæÁ§∫Ê≥®ÈáäÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÊàëÁöÑÊ≥®Èáä (F8232_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì Ê≥®Èáä (SAP_BW_BC_COMMENT_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂëòÂ∑• (SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE)‚Äù„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî® ‚ÄúÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä (S_RS_CMT)‚Äú ÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊåâÊñáÊ°£Â≠òÂÇ®ÂêçÁß∞ÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ

Ë¶ÅÊõ¥ÊîπÊàñËÄÖÂà†Èô§Ê≥®ÈáäÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÁÆ°ÁêÜÊ≥®Èáä (F8233_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì Ê≥®ÈáäÁÆ°ÁêÜ (SAP_BW_BC_COMMENT_ADM_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê‰∏ìÂÆ∂ (SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST)‚Äù„ÄÇ‰ΩøÁî® ‚ÄúÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®Èáä (S_RS_CMT)‚Äú ÈôêÂà∂Á±ªÂûãÔºåÂèØ‰ª•ÊåâÊñáÊ°£Â≠òÂÇ®ÂêçÁß∞ÈôêÂà∂ÂØπÂàÜÊûêÂçïÂÖÉÊ†ºÊ≥®ÈáäÁöÑËÆøÈóÆ„ÄÇ

 

Êñ∞Â¢ûAIËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩ

‰∫ßÂìÅËé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8348) Â∫îÁî®‰∏≠Êñ∞Â¢ûAI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩ„ÄÇÁõÆÂâçSAPÁ≥ªÁªüÂú®‚ÄúÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØî‚ÄùËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠È¢ÑËÆæ‰∫Ü4‰∏™‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂàÜÊûêÂèÇÊï∞Ôºö

  1. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÂâç 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄÈ´òÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑ„ÄÇ
  2. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄ‰ΩéÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÁªÑ„ÄÇ
  3. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÂâç 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÂä†ÊúÄÈ´òÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅ„ÄÇ
  4. ÊåâÊúÄÂ§ßËæπÈôÖÂà©Ê∂¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂêé 5 ‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅÔºöÊ†πÊçÆÊúüÈó¥ÂêåÊØîËßÜÂõæ‰∏≠ÁöÑËæπÈôÖË¥°ÁåÆ II ÔºåÊü•ÊâæÂπ∂Ëß£ÈáäÂà©Ê∂¶Â¢ûÈïøÊúÄ‰ΩéÁöÑ‰∫î‰∏™‰∫ßÂìÅ„ÄÇ

 

Ë¶Å‰ΩøÁî®AI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÂäüËÉΩÔºåÈúÄË¶ÅÂ∞ÜIAMÂ∫îÁî®‚ÄùÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå (F8405_TRAN)‚Äù ÂàÜÈÖçÂà∞Áî®Êà∑ÔºåËØ•IAMÂ∫îÁî®ÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩï‚ÄúÂàÜÊûê ‚Äì ÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜå‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØü (SAP_BW_BC_RVB_ABI_PC)‚ÄùÔºåËØ•‰∏öÂä°ÁõÆÂΩïÈªòËÆ§ÂàÜÈÖçËá≥‰∏öÂä°ËßíËâ≤‚ÄúÂëòÂ∑• (SAP_BR_EMPLOYEE)‚Äù„ÄÇ

Êà™Ê≠¢Ëá≥SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 ÁâàÊú¨ÔºåÂêåÊ†∑ÊîØÊåÅAI ËæÖÂä©‰∏öÂä°Ê¥ûÂØüÔºàFinancial Business InsightsÔºâÂäüËÉΩÁöÑÂàÜÊûêÊä•Ë°®Â∫îÁî®ÂåÖÊã¨Ôºå‰ΩÜ‰∏çÈôê‰∫éÔºö

  3. ÂÖ¨Âè∏Ëé∑Âà©ËÉΩÂäõÂÆ°Ê†∏ÊâãÂÜåÔºàÊ®°ÊùøÔºâ (F8300)

entry.title: Auto Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Automatic Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery ‚Äì SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Nested Handling Units (HUs) mean packing one Handling Unit inside another Handling Unit.
  • For example, cartons packed into a pallet, where each carton and the pallet have their own HU number.

Step 1: Maintain Packaging Material Types. The menu path is shown in the screenshot below.

Note: I have created 2 Packaging Material types:

  • Pallet
  • Carton

Step 2: Define Material group for Packaging Materials

 

  • Created Packing Material groups for Pallet and Carton.

Step 3: Define Allowed Packaging Materials

  • Map the Packing Material Type with the Packing Material Group

  • Note - For Nested HUs, it is mandatory to cross-map Packing Material Types with Packing Material Groups.

This means:

  • Carton groups must allow pallet types, and
  • Pallet groups must allow carton types,
  • so that inner HUs can be packed into outer HUs without errors.

Step 4: Assign Number Range intervals to Packaging Material Type

  • Assign a number range to the created Packing Material Types for the respective plant and storage location.

Step 5: Created packing materials in MM01 using Material Type VERP and assign the relevant Packing Material Group and Pack. Material Type in the ‚ÄúMatl Grp Pack. Matls, Packing Material type‚Äù fields under the Basic Data view/Sales: General Plant data. Additionally, assign the appropriate HU Type and also created SFG Material.

In this scenario, two packing materials are created:

  • CARTONBOX with Packing Material Type CARTON
  • PALLET1 with Packing Material Type PALLET
  • 42 with SFG type.

 

Step 6:  Create Packing Instructions using T-Code: POP1

  • Please note that the Handling Unit (HU) number is generated only for the Load Carrier maintained in a Packaging Instruction.
  • As a result, to generate HUs for both cartons and pallets, each must be defined as a Load Carrier. Since a Packaging Instruction can contain only one Load Carrier, separate Packaging Instructions are required for cartons and pallets.
  • Based on this approach, the following Packaging Instructions have been created:

  • Created Packing Instruction ‚ÄúAutoPack‚Äù, added Components for Cotton Box.

  • Maintain check profile.

  • Check and save.

  • A separate Packaging Instruction is created for the pallet by adding the PALLET material as Item Category ‚ÄúP‚Äù and the AUTOPACK packaging instruction as Item Category ‚ÄúI‚Äù. Maintain the required quantities, then check and save.

Step 7: For automatic determination of the Packaging Instruction, create a condition record using T-code POF1.

  • Select ‚ÄúRCPT‚Äù standard for Inbound delivery.

  • Assign the SFG material and the ‚ÄòPALLET‚Äô Packaging Instruction in the determination record.

Step 8:  Enable Auto Packing in Delivery Types

  • Selected Standard ‚ÄúEL‚Äù delivery type for Inbound delivery
  • Enabled ‚ÄúAutomatic Packing‚Äù and save

The above are the configuration steps. The functional flow is explained below.

  • Created PO by selecting Confirmation key.

  • Create the inbound delivery, select the line item, and click ‚ÄòAuto Packing‚Äô. The system automatically packs the material.

In this scenario, Material 42 ‚Äì SFG Material is maintained.

  • Each Carton Box is defined to carry 25 KG of SFG material.
  • Multiple Carton Boxes are then packed into a Pallet, where one pallet contains 4 carton boxes.
  • A Purchase Order is created for 100 KG of 42 SFG material.

During Inbound Delivery Auto Packing, the system performs the packing automatically as follows:

  • 100 KG of SFG material is packed into 4 Carton HUs (25 KG each).
  • These 4 Carton HUs are nested and packed into 1 Pallet HU.

This demonstrates Nested Handling Unit (HU) auto packing, where inner Carton HUs are packed into an outer Pallet HU, and each level is assigned its own HU number automatically by the system.
